info.title: Mittwald API
info.description:
## Introduction

This OpenAPI spec documents the mittwald API. It follows the
[OpenAPI 3.0.0 specification](https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v3.0.0.html).

## Authentication

You will need an API token to access the API. You can obtain one by logging into the
[mStudio](https://studio.mittwald.de) and navigating to the
["API Tokens" section in the user menu](https://studio.mittwald.de/app/profile/api-tokens).

When making requests to the API, you can authenticate by passing your API token in the `X-Access-Token` header or as a
bearer token.

## Rate Limiting

Please note that usage of the API is rate-limited to prevent abuse. You can inspect the rate limiting for your current
user by observing the `X-Ratelimit-*` headers included in each response.

## mStudio

A main consumer of the mittwald API is the management interface for our customers, the
[mStudio](https://studio.mittwald.de).

## Contact and support

For support, please use the [mStudio support area](https://studio.mittwald.de/app/support/conversations) or drop us an
email at [support@mittwald.de](mailto:support@mittwald.de).

For security issues, please report to [security@mittwald.de](mailto:security@mittwald.de).

tags.name: Project
tags.description: The project API allows you to manage your projects, and also any kinds of user memberships concerning these projects.

tags.name: Backup
tags.description: The backup API allows you to manage your project backups.

tags.name: SSH/SFTP User
tags.description: The SSH/SFTP User API allows you to manage your SSH/SFTP users within a project.

tags.name: Cronjob
tags.description: The cronjob API allows you to manage cronjobs within a project.

tags.name: App
tags.description: The App API allows you to manage your apps within a project, and all the system softwares that are installed as dependencies.

tags.name: Project File System
tags.description: The filesystem API allows you to directly access the filesystem of your project.

tags.name: Contract
tags.description: The contract API allows you to manage your contracts and orders

tags.name: Database
tags.description: The database API allows you to manage your databases, like MySQL and Redis databases.

tags.name: Domain
tags.description: The domain API allows you to manage your domains, DNS records and ingress resources.

tags.name: Conversation
tags.description: The conversation API allows you to manage your support conversations.

tags.name: Customer
tags.description: The customer API allows you to manage your own organizations and users.

tags.name: User
tags.description: The user API allows you to manage your own user and access information of other users that might be visible to you.

tags.name: Notification
tags.description: The notification API allows you to manage your notifications.

tags.name: File
tags.description: The file API allows you to manage your files, for example for conversations attachments and avatar uploads.

tags.name: Mail
tags.description: The mail API allows you to manage your mail accounts.

tags.name: Article
tags.description: The article API allows you to read article information.

tags.name: Container
tags.description: The container API allows you to manage your stacks, containers, volumes and registries.

tags.name: Page Insights
tags.description: The page insights API allows you to get page insights information.

tags.name: Relocation
tags.description: The relocation API allows you to manage your relocations.

tags.name: Marketplace
tags.description: The marketplace API allows you to manage extensions and more information regaring the marketplace.

de.mittwald.v1.app.Action.description: An Action is a string that describes a runtime concerning action which can be executed on an AppInstallation or an  App  can be capable of.

de.mittwald.v1.app.App.description: An App is to be understood as a manifest for AppInstallations. E.g. 'WordPress' only exists inside our ecosystem, because there is an  App -Manifest for it.

de.mittwald.v1.app.AppInstallationStatus.description: AppInstallationStatus describes the overall runtime status of an AppInstallation.

de.mittwald.v1.app.AppUpdatePolicy.description: AppUpdatePolicy describes which updates should be applied automatically by our systems.

de.mittwald.v1.app.AppInstallation.description: An AppInstallation is a concrete manifestation of an App in a specific AppVersion.

de.mittwald.v1.app.AppInstallationLifecy.description: The AppInstallationLifecycle can be used to express a specific point in the AppInstallation Lifecycle, e.g. while installing a new AppInstallation.

de.mittwald.v1.app.AppVersion.description: An AppVersion is an officially supported version of an App, containing the necessary and recommended configuration und dependencies.

de.mittwald.v1.app.BreakingNote.description: A BreakingNote is a hint that something serious has changed in the AppVersion containing it, so an automatic update is not possible.

de.mittwald.v1.app.DatabaseDependency.description: A DatabaseDependency is a generic description of need for a database, used by AppVersions.

de.mittwald.v1.app.InstalledSystemSoftwa.description: InstalledSystemSoftware describes the currently configured and installed SystemSoftwareVersion of a SystemSoftware besides the desired SystemSoftwareUpdatePolicy inside an AppInstallation.

de.mittwald.v1.app.LinkedDatabase.description: LinkedDatabase is a reference to a concrete Database and DatabaseUsers.

de.mittwald.v1.app.RequestHandlerRequire.description: RequestHandlerRequirement describes the necessary properties to internally resolve the request handler or process to start.

de.mittwald.v1.app.SavedUserInput.description: A SavedUserInput is an entered value for a desired UserInput of an AppVersion or SystemSoftwareVersion.

de.mittwald.v1.app.SystemSoftwareDepende.description: A SystemSoftwareDependency is a description of a need for a specific SystemSoftware in a semver versionRange.

de.mittwald.v1.app.SystemSoftwareUpdateP.description: SystemSoftwareUpdatePolicy describes which updates should be applied automatically by our systems.

de.mittwald.v1.app.SystemSoftware.description: A SystemSoftware is a software that can be installed for an AppInstallation but mostly is not itself externally reachable and/or deliverable.

de.mittwald.v1.app.SystemSoftwareVersion.description: A SystemSoftwareVersion is an officially  supported version of a SystemSoftware, containing the necessary and recommended configuration und dependencies.

de.mittwald.v1.app.UserInput.description: A UserInput is a description of an information which cannot be determined or estimated by mittwald, but has to be given by the person who is requesting an AppInstallation or SystemSoftware.

dataSource.description: Optional field to tell the frontend, which data to put into the select.

de.mittwald.v1.app.UserInputDataType.description: UserInputDataType is an enum, describing the possible data types of a UserInput.

de.mittwald.v1.app.UserInputFormat.description: UserInputFormat is an enum, describing the possible data formats of a UserInput, the given values can be validated against.

de.mittwald.v1.app.UserInputPositionMeta.description: UserInputPositionMeta is a utility information, helping to position the UserInput properly on the frontend.

de.mittwald.v1.app.VersionStatus.description: VersionStatus describes the current and desired version of something like the AppVersion of an AppInstallation. If diverging, an internal process is going to assert, the current value will be aligned.

The object containing the new status of the conversation.
The statuses `open` and `answered` are displayed identically to the users as an open
(unresolved) conversation. A conversation with the status `closed` is a solved issue.
Closed conversations can be reopened by setting the status to `open` or by sending a
message in the conversation.

get.description:
The OAuth 2.0 client requests authorization from the resource owner according to
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749). The
authorization request is made indirectly via the authorization
server as an intermediary.

parameters.description: Access Token of the Resource Owner.
parameters.name: x-access-token

parameters.description:
Can be set in combination with `Authorization`-Header to grant consent for the requested scopes.
If set to `true`, the scopes will be marked as consented and the authorization server will
redirect the user-agent back to the client.
If set to `false`, the authorization server will redirect the user-agent back to the client with an
access denied error.
If not set and `Authorization`-Header is set, the user will be asked for consent.
parameters.name: grant_consent

parameters.description: The grant type. Must be set to `authorization_code` for this endpoint.
parameters.name: grant_type

parameters.description: The response type. Must be set to `code` for this endpoint.
parameters.name: response_type

parameters.description:
The client identifier as described in
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-2.2).
parameters.name: client_id

parameters.description:
The redirection URI to which the authorization server
directs the user-agent back after the authorization
endpoint. Must be a valid URI.
parameters.name: redirect_uri

parameters.description:
The scope of the access request as described by
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-3.3).
parameters.name: scope

parameters.description:
An opaque value used by the client to maintain state
between the request and callback. The authorization server
includes this value when redirecting the user-agent back to
the client. The parameter SHOULD be used for preventing
cross-site request forgery as described in
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-10.12).
parameters.name: state

parameters.description:
The code challenge as described by
[RFC7636](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636#section-4.2).
If the authorization code flow should be used with Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE), this parameter
  must be set and the code verifier has to be given to the token endpoint.
parameters.name: code_challenge

parameters.description:
The code challenge method as described in
[RFC7636](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636#section-4.3).
If used, the code_challenge must be set as well and the code verifier
has to be given to the token endpoint
parameters.name: code_challenge_method

302.description:
The authorization server redirects the user-agent by
sending the HTTP response with status code 302 and the HTTP
`Location`-Header field containing the authorization endpoint URI
with either the query parameters `code` added, if successful or `error`
and `error_description` added, if not. Fore more Information see
[Authorization Response](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2).

400.description:
The request is missing a required parameter, includes an
invalid parameter value, includes a parameter more than
once, or is otherwise malformed.

get.summary: Obtain authorization from the resource owner.

post.description:
The OAuth 2.0 client retrieves an Access Token from an existing authorization code according to
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749).

parameters.description:
The client credentials (`client_id` and `client_secret`), separated with a colon
and base64 encoded as described in
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-2.3.1).
Submitting the `client_id` and `client_secret` as request-body as suggested is forbidden.
parameters.name: Authorization

code.description: The authorization code received from the authorization server.

code_verifier.description:
The code verifier used to generate the code challenge as described in
[RFC7636](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636#section-4.1).
If the authorization flow was initiated with a code challenge, this parameter is required.

grant_type.description:
The grant type as described in
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.3).

redirect_uri.description:
The redirection URI used in the authorization request.
Must be a valid URI.

access_token.description: The access token issued by the authorization server.

expires_in.description:
The lifetime in seconds of the access token. For
example, the value "3600" denotes that the access
token will expire in one hour from the time the
response was generated.

scope.description:
The scope of the access token as described by
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-3.3).

token_type.description:
The type of the token issued as described in
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-7.1).

200.description:
The authorization server issues an access token as described in
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-5.1).

400.description:
The request of an access token is invalid as described in
[RFC6749](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-5.2).

post.summary: Retrieve Access Token from Authorization Code.
